Meantime, on their way back to Satsuma, Hisamitsu's troops attacked British people who tried to cross the procession of the lord of the Satsuma clan in the village of Namamugi (the Namamugi incident).
sen.cmt: now part of Tsurumi ward, Yokohama の部分を除きました。

sen.j: 勅使に屈した幕府をさらに追い込むべく三条実美・姉小路公知ら尊王攘夷派の過激公卿が、長州藩などの勢力を背景に将軍に上洛を命ずる一方、攘夷の勅命を請願するなど、朝政を壟断しつつあった。
sen.e: During this period, radical court nobles who advocated Sonno-joi acted as if they were the leaders of the country; for example, Sanemi SANJO and Kintomo ANENOKOJI, pressing further the government that had succumbed to accept the imperial messenger, ordered the government to have the shogun to show up in Kyoto, with a backdrop of the strong Choshu clan, while they asked the emperor to grant an imperial order to expel foreigners.

During this period, radical court nobles who advocated Sonno-joi such as Sanemi SANJO and Kintomo ANENOKOJI acted as if they were leaders of the country, using the influence of the Choshu clan to further press a government which had already yielded to the imperial messenger, and ordered the shogun to go to Kyoto, while they petitioned the emperor to grant an imperial order to expel foreigners.

During this period, radical court nobles who advocated Sonno Joi ha such as Sanemi SANJO and Kintomo ANENOKOJI acted as if they were leaders of the country, using the influence of the Choshu clan to further press a government which had already yielded to the imperial messenger, and ordered the shogun to go to Kyoto, while they petitioned the emperor to grant an imperial order to expel foreigners.

sen.j: 将軍上洛を求める圧力に抗しきれず、文久3年（1863年）家茂は将軍としては200年ぶり（3代徳川家光以来）の上洛を余儀なくされ、来る5月10日の攘夷決行を約束させられた。
sen.e: The shogun Iemochi, who could not resist to the requirement, finally visited Kyoto in 1863 as an incumbent shogun for the first time in 200 years since the visit made by the 3rd shogun Iemistsu, and was forced to promise on expelling foreigners.

Shogun Iemochi, who could not resist their requirement, finally visited Kyoto in 1863 and was the first shogun to be forced to do so in 200 years (the previous time being the visit made by the 3rd shogun Iemistsu), and was forced to promise to expel foreigners.

Shogun Iemochi, who could not resist their requirement, finally visited Kyoto in 1863 and was the first shogun to be forced to do so in 200 years (the previous time being the visit made by the 3rd shogun Iemistsu), and was forced to promise to expel foreigners, this coming May 10.
sen.cmt: 「5月10日」の訳漏れです。最後に加えました。

sen.j: 約束の日である5月10日、長州藩は久坂玄瑞らの指揮の下、関門海峡を通過する外国商船に砲撃を加え、攘夷を決行する。
sen.e: On the promised day, May 10, under the direction of Genzui KUSAKA and others, the Choshu clan attacked foreign vessels crossing the Kanmon Channel with gunfire.
On the agreed date of May 10, under the direction of Genzui KUSAKA and others, the Choshu clan attacked foreign vessels crossing the Kanmon Channel with gunfire.
On the agreed date of May 10, under the direction of Genzui KUSAKA and others, the Choshu clan attacked foreign vessels crossing the Kanmon Channel with gunfire.

sen.j: しかし同月末に外国船に反撃され、砲台を占拠されるなど、実際には攘夷の困難さを身をもって知ることとなる（四国艦隊下関砲撃事件）。
sen.e: But the foreign vessels fought back in the end of the same month and occupied the gun battery in Choshu; this incident, after all, provided a good opportunity for the Choshu clan to rethink how difficult to expel foreigners (Battles of Shimonoseki).

However, the foreign vessels fought back at the end of the same month and occupied the gun battery in Choshu (the Battles of Shimonoseki); actually, this incident provided a good opportunity for the Choshu clan to reconsider how difficult it would be to expel foreigners.

However, the foreign vessels fought back at the end of the same month and occupied the gun battery in Choshu (the Battles of Shimonoseki); actually, this incident provided a good opportunity for the Choshu clan to reconsider how difficult it would be to expel foreigners.

sen.j: また藩兵の軟弱さを嘆いた長州藩士高杉晋作は、新たに武士以外の身分を含む奇兵隊などの諸隊を結成し、後の長州藩の武力となっていく。
sen.e: In the meantime, Shinsaku TAKASUGI, a member of the Choshu clan, deplored their weak troops and started to form new groups to include ordinary people, non-samurai class people, such as Kihei-tai, by which the Choshu clan will be helped.

In the meantime, Shinsaku TAKASUGI, a member of the Choshu clan, lamented their weak troops and started to form new groups to include ordinary, non-samurai class people, such as Kihei-tai, which could help the Choshu clan.

In the meantime, Shinsaku TAKASUGI, a member of the Choshu clan, lamented their weak troops and started to form new groups to include ordinary, non-samurai class people, such as Kihei-tai (a cavalry squad), which could help the Choshu clan.
sen.cmt: Kihei-tai の後に括弧で補足を加えました。

sen.j: また、生麦事件の賠償問題がこじれたことから7月2日薩摩藩と英国の間にも戦争が勃発（薩英戦争参照）。
sen.e: On the other hand, the Satsuma clan also had a war with the Britain, after the negotiation over the compensation for the damage caused by the Namamugi incident was broken up (Anglo-Satsuma War).
Also, war broke out between the Satsuma clan and Britain, after negotiations over compensation for damage caused by the Namamugi incident turned sour (Anglo-Satsuma War).
Also, war broke out between the Satsuma clan and Britain on July 2, after negotiations over compensation for damage caused by the Namamugi incident turned sour (Anglo-Satsuma War).
sen.cmt: 「7月2日」の訳漏れのため、加えました。

sen.j: 善戦するも鹿児島市市街の一部が焼失し、薩摩藩もまた攘夷の不可能性を悟ることとなった。
sen.e: The Satsuma clan fought well but they lost a part of the city, and found expelling foreigners nearly impossible.
The Satsuma clan fought well but they lost a part of the city, and found expelling foreigners nearly impossible.
The Satsuma clan fought well but they lost a part of the city, and found expelling foreigners nearly impossible.

sen.j: 尊攘派の蹉跌（1863年～1864年）
sen.e: Thwarted ambition of Sonno-Joi (1863 to 1864)
The thwarted ambition of Sonno-Joi (1863 to 1864)
The thwarted ambition of sonjo party (1863 - 1864)
sen.cmt: Sonno-Joi→sonjo party に修正し、括弧内の「to」は他と同様に「-」にしました。

sen.j: この頃、京都へ尊王攘夷派の志士が集い、「天誅」と称して反対派を暗殺するなど、治安が極端に悪化。
sen.e: During this period, the public order in Kyoto got deteriorated because groups of people who advocated the idea of Sonno-Joi gathered there from across the country, some of which assassinated the opposition, insisting that was a punishment from the heaven.

During this period, public order in Kyoto deteriorated because groups of people who advocated the idea of Sonno-Joi gathered there from across the country and assassinated members of the opposition, insisting that it was a punishment from heaven.

During this period, public order in Kyoto deteriorated because groups of people who advocated Sonno Joi ha gathered there from across the country and assassinated members of the opposition, insisting that it was a punishment from heaven.
sen.cmt: the idea of Sonno-Joi→Sonno Joi ha としました。

sen.j: 逆に尊攘派の代表と見られた姉小路公知が暗殺される事件（朔平門外の変）も起き、犯行に関与したとみられた薩摩藩など公武合体派の勢力が一時低下した。
sen.e: In the meantime, Kintomo ANEGAKOJI, who was regarded as a leader of the Sonno-Joi movement (Sakuheimon Incident), some groups that had worked for the union of the imperial court and the shogunate including the Satsuma clan, were suspected to be responsible for the incident and reduced their power.

In the meantime, Kintomo ANEGAKOJI, who was regarded as a leader of the Sonno-Joi movement, was assassinated (the Sakuheimon incident); some groups that had worked for the union of the imperial court and the shogunate, including the Satsuma clan, were suspected to be responsible for the incident and for a while their authority fell.
sen.cmt: Wording. No mention of assassination in original translation.
sen.e: In the meantime, Kintomo ANEGAKOJI, who was regarded as a leader of sonjo party, was assassinated (the Sakuheimon incident); some groups that had worked for kobu-gattai, including the Satsuma clan, were suspected to be responsible for the incident and for a while their authority fell.
sen.cmt: the Sonno-Joi movement→sonjo partyとし、「公武合体」→初出でないのでkobu-gattaiとしました。

sen.j: 尊攘派の擡頭により朝廷・幕府政治の混乱が起きていることを憂えた孝明天皇の意をくみ、久邇宮朝彦親王は極秘に会津藩・薩摩藩に長州藩の追放を命ずる。
sen.e: Understanding the Emperor Komei was worried about the confused political circumstances of the imperial court and of the shogunate, as Sonno-Joi groups emerged visibly, Imperial Prince Kuninomiya Asahiko secretly ordered the Aizu and Satsuma clans to expel the Choshu clan.

Understanding that the Emperor Komei was worried about the emergence of Sonno-Joi groups and the resulting confused political circumstances of the imperial court and of the shogunate, Imperial Prince Kuninomiya Asahiko secretly ordered the Aizu and Satsuma clans to expel the Choshu clan.

Understanding that the Emperor Komei was worried about the emergence of sonjo party and the resulting confused political circumstances of the imperial court and of the shogunate, Imperial Prince Kuninomiya Asahiko secretly ordered the Aizu and Satsuma clans to expel the Choshu clan.
sen.cmt: Sonno-Joi groups→sonjo partyに修正しました。

sen.j: 文久3年8月18日、宮廷の御門を制圧した会津・薩摩は、長州藩兵および三条ら7人の公卿を長州への撤退させるクーデタを決行し（八月十八日の政変、七卿落ち）、長州藩系の尊攘勢力の一掃に成功した。
sen.e: On August 18, 1863 Aizu and Satsuma clans who took the control of the gate of the court beforehand, carried a coup d'etat and successfully cleaned up the Sonno-Joi people that related to the Choshu clan out of Kyotot, letting the Choshu's troops to withdraw, and expelling seven court nobles including SANJO, to Choshu (Coup of August 18, the exile of the seven nobles from Kyoto).

On August 18, 1863 the Aizu and Satsuma clans took control of the gate of the Imperial court, and carried out a coup forcing the Choshu clan and seven nobles, including SANJO, to retreat to Choshu, successfully crushing the power of those Sonno-Joi related to the Choshu clan (Coup of August 18, the exile of the seven nobles from Kyoto).
sen.cmt: Wording. I have never heard the phrase coup d'etat.
sen.e: On August 18, 1863 the Aizu and Satsuma clans took control of the gate of the Imperial court, and carried out a coup forcing the Choshu clan and seven nobles, including Sanjo, to retreat to Choshu, successfully crushing the power of those sonjo party related to the Choshu clan (Coup of August 18, the exile of the seven nobles from Kyoto).
sen.cmt: SANJO→Sanjo, Sonno-Joi→sonjo partyに修正しました。

sen.j: いっぽう幕権強化・雄藩連合などの様々な思惑を孕みつつ、文久3年12月に徳川慶喜・松平春嶽・松平容保・伊達宗城（宇和島藩主）・島津久光による参預会議が開催され、神奈川鎖港談判、長州藩の処置、大坂港の防備強化などの議題が話し合われたが、将軍後見職の徳川慶喜の非協力的態度に春嶽・久光らが反撥して帰国したため、早くも翌年3月には崩壊。
sen.e: Leaving various ideas, such as intensifying the power of the bakufu, and the alliance of major clans, as they are, a council meeting was held on December 1863 by Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA,Shungaku MATSUDAIRA, Katamori MATSUDAIRA, Munenari DATE (the lord of Uwajima clan), and Hisamitsu SHIMAZU to discuss the condition of the port of Kanagawa, the treatment of Choshu clan, and the protection buildup of the port of Osaka, but it failed as early as in March 1864, when Shungaku and Hisamitsu got upset against Yoshino TOKUGAWA, a guardian of the shogun, who was not cooperative at all.

Leaving various ideas, such as reinforcing the power of the bakufu, and the alliance of major clans, as they were, a council meeting was held on December 1863 by Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, Shungaku MATSUDAIRA, Katamori MATSUDAIRA, Munenari DATE (the lord of Uwajima clan), and Hisamitsu SHIMAZU to discuss the condition of the port of Kanagawa, the treatment of the Choshu clan, and strengthening the defences of the port of Osaka, but it failed as early as in March 1864, when Shungaku and Hisamitsu became upset with Yoshino TOKUGAWA, a guardian of the shogun, who was not cooperative at all.

Leaving various ideas, such as reinforcing the power of the bakufu, and the alliance of major clans, as they were, a council meeting was held on December 1863 by Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, Shungaku MATSUDAIRA, Katamori MATSUDAIRA, Munenari DATE (the lord of Uwajima clan), and Hisamitsu SHIMAZU to discuss the condition of the port of Kanagawa, the treatment of the Choshu clan, and strengthening the defences of the port of Osaka, but it failed as early as in March 1864, when Shungaku and Hisamitsu became upset with Yoshino TOKUGAWA, a guardian of the shogun, who was not cooperative at all.

sen.j: 参預会議体制はわずか数ヶ月しか持たなかった。
sen.e: The councilors' meeting system survived only for a few months.
The councilors' meeting system survived for only a few months.
The councilors' meeting system survived for only a few months.

sen.j: この後、朝廷から禁裏御守衛総督・摂海防禦指揮に任ぜられた慶喜は、京都守護職松平容保（会津藩主）・京都所司代松平定敬（桑名藩主）兄弟らとともに、江戸の幕閣から半ば独立した動きをみせることとなる（一会桑政権）。
sen.e: After the collapse, Yoshinobu, who was appointed as Kinri goshuei sotoku (director-general to guard Kinri Palace) and director of protecting the sea around Osaka, became rather independent from the cabinet official of the shogunate, along with brothers of Katamori MATSUDAIRA, the lord of Aizu clan, and Sadaaki MATSUDAIRA, the lord of Kuwana clan (Ichikaiso Government)..

After the collapse, Yoshinobu, who was appointed as Kinri goshuei sotoku (director-general to guard Kinri Palace) and director of protection of the sea around Osaka, along with the brothers Katamori MATSUDAIRA, military govenor of Kyoto and the lord of the Aizu clan, and Sadaaki MATSUDAIRA, Kyoto deputy and the lord of the Kuwana clan, became semi-independent from the cabinet officials of the shogunate (Ichikaiso Government).

After the collapse, Yoshinobu, who was appointed as Kinri goshuei sotoku (director-general to guard Imperial Palace) and director of protection of the sea around Osaka, along with the brothers Katamori MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the Aizu clan), Kyoto shugoshiki, and Sadaaki MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the Kuwana clan), Kyoto shoshidai (representative of shoshi), became semi-independent from the cabinet officials of the shogunate (Ichikaiso Government).
sen.cmt: Kinri Palace→Imperial Palaceに, 「守護職」military govenor of Kyoto→Kyoto shugoshiki, 「所司代」を用語集の通りに修正しました。

sen.j: この頃、各地で尊攘過激派による実力行使の動きが見られたが、いずれも失敗に終わっている。
sen.e: Various radical Sonno-Joi groups across the country tried to use of forces at the time, but all actions fell through.
Various radical Sonno-Joi groups across the country tried to use force at the time, but all attempts fell through.
Various radical sonjo party across the country tried to use force at the time, but all attempts fell through.
sen.cmt: Sonno-Joi groups→sonjo party としました。

sen.j: 文久3年（1863年）8月大和国では公卿中山忠光、吉村寅太郎・池内蔵太（土佐藩士）、松本奎堂（三河刈谷藩士）、藤本鉄石（岡山藩士）、さらには河内国の大地主水郡善之祐らも加わった天誅組の変が勃発し、続いて但馬国では沢宣嘉（前年京都から追放された七卿の一人）・平野国臣（福岡藩士）らによる生野の変が連鎖的に発生した。
sen.e: In August 1868, the Tenchu-gumi incident was caused in Yamato by Tadamitsu NAKAYAMA, a court noble, Torataro YOSHIMURA, Kurata IKEUHI of Tosa clan, Keido MATSUMOTO of Kariya clan, Tesseki FUJIMOTO of Okayama clan, Zennosuke NIGORI, a huge landlord in Kawachi, and the Ikuno incident happened in Tajima in rapid succession by Nobuyoshi SAWA (one of the seven court nobles who was exiled from Kyoto in the previous year) and Kuniomi HIRANO of Fukuoka clan.

In August 1868, the Tenchu-gumi incident was caused in Yamato by Tadamitsu NAKAYAMA, a court noble, Torataro YOSHIMURA, Kurata IKEUHI of the Tosa clan, Keido MATSUMOTO of the Kariya clan, Tesseki FUJIMOTO of the Okayama clan, and Zennosuke NIGORI, a powerful landlord in Kawachi, and this rapidly led to Nobuyoshi SAWA (one of the seven court nobles who was exiled from Kyoto in the previous year) and Kuniomi HIRANO of the Fukuoka clan causing the Ikuno incident in Tajima.

In August 1868, the Tenchu-gumi incident was caused in Yamato Province by Tadamitsu NAKAYAMA, Kugyo (the top court officials), Torataro YOSHIMURA, Kurata IKEUCHI (the Tosa clan), Keido MATSUMOTO (the Mikawa Kariya clan), Tesseki FUJIMOTO (the Okayama clan), and Zennosuke NIGORI, a powerful landlord in Kawachi Province, and this rapidly led to Nobuyoshi SAWA (one of the seven court nobles who were exiled from Kyoto in the previous year) and Kuniomi HIRANO (the Fukuoka clan) causing the Ikuno incident in Tajima Province.
sen.cmt: Yamato, Kawachi, TajimaにそれぞれProvinceを、（～藩士）の括弧をそれぞれ加え、「公卿」を用語集の通りに修正、IKEUHI→IKEUCHI、who was→who wereに修正しました。

sen.j: これらの事件は倒幕を目的とした最初の軍事的行動として、後世から見た歴史的な意味は大きいものの、この時点では無残な結末となった。
sen.e: From the current point of view, those incidents were significant because they are the first military actions in order to overthrow the bakufu, but all of them failed miserably at the time.
From the current point of view, those incidents are significant because they were the first military actions attempting to overthrow the bakufu, but all of them failed miserably.
From the current point of view, those incidents are significant because they were the first military actions attempting to overthrow the bakufu, but all of them failed miserably.

sen.j: また土佐藩では武市瑞山が率いる土佐勤王党（前年に藩執政吉田東洋を暗殺）が弾圧され尊攘勢力は次第に後退していった。
sen.e: In Tosa clan, Sonno-Joi forces gradually waned as Tosakino Party (loyalist clique of Tosa) led by Zuisan TAKECHI was suppressed (Toyo YOSHIDA, an administrator of the clan, was assassinated year before).

Sonno-Joi forces gradually waned in the Tosa clan as the Tosakino Party, a loyalist clique of Tosa led by Zuisan TAKECHI, was suppressed (Toyo YOSHIDA, an administrator of the clan, was assassinated the year before).

Sonno-Joi forces gradually waned in the Tosa clan as the Tosakino Party, a loyalist clique of Tosa led by Zuisan TAKECHI, was suppressed (Toyo YOSHIDA, an administrator of the clan, was assassinated the year before).

sen.j: さらに水戸藩では元治元年（1864年）3月、藤田小四郎・武田耕雲斎ら天狗党が筑波山で挙兵。
sen.e: In Mito domain, Tenguto party, including Koshiro FUJITA and Kounsai TAKEDA, raised an army in Mt. Tsukuba in March 1864.
In Mito domain, Tenguto party, whose members included Koshiro FUJITA and Kounsai TAKEDA, raised an army in Mt. Tsukuba in March 1864.
In Mito domain, Tengu-to party, whose members included Koshiro FUJITA and Kounsai TAKEDA, raised an army in Mt. Tsukuba in March 1864.

sen.j: 水戸藩の要請を受けた幕府軍の追撃により壊滅させられる事件も発生した（天狗党の乱参照）。
sen.e: Another incident was destroyed by the army of government that was in response to the requirement from Mito domain (Tenguto no Ran, rebellion of Tenguto)
Another incident involved the pursuit and destruction of the bakufu's army, as demanded by Mito domain (Tenguto no Ran, rebellion of Tenguto).
Another incident involved the pursuit and destruction of the bakufu's army, as demanded by Mito domain (See the Tengu Party War).
sen.cmt: 括弧内を修正しました。

sen.j: このような状況下、前年の八月十八日の政変以降影響力を減退していた尊王攘夷派の中心・長州藩では、京都への進発論が沸騰。
sen.e: Under these circumstances, in the Choshu domain, which had been a center of the Sonno-Joi movement but started to wane after the Coup of August 18 in the previous year, an idea to move for Kyoto became significantly prominent.

Under these circumstances, in Choshu domain, which had been the center of the Sonno-Joi movement but started to wane after the Coup of August 18 in the previous year, debate began over a proposed move to Kyoto.

Under these circumstances, in Choshu domain, which had been the center of the Sonno Joi Movement but started to wane after the Coup of August 18 in the previous year, debate began over a proposed move to Kyoto.
sen.cmt: Sonno-Joi movement→Sonno Joi Movementに修正しました。

sen.j: 折から京都治安維持に当たっていた会津藩預かりの新撰組が、池田屋事件で長州藩など尊攘派の志士数人を殺害したため、火に油を注ぐこととなり、ついに長州藩兵は上京。
sen.e: In the meantime, Shinsengumi, an organization under the control of Aizu clan, in charge of protecting Kyoto at the time, killed several supporters of Sonno-Joi, including member of Choshu clan in the Iledaya incident; this put the fire on the debate in the Chosu domain and the Choshu troops finally moved up to Kyoto.

In the meantime, Shinsengumi, an organization under the control of the Aizu clan and in charge of protecting Kyoto at the time, killed several supporters of Sonno-Joi, including members of the Choshu clan in the Iledaya incident; this added fuel to the debate in Choshu domain and the Choshu troops finally moved to Kyoto.

In the meantime, Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate), under the control of the Aizu clan and in charge of protecting Kyoto at the time, killed several supporters of sonjo party, including members of the Choshu clan in the Ikedaya incident; this added fuel to the debate in Choshu domain and the Choshu troops finally moved to Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 「新撰組」を用語集の通りにし、Sonno-Joi→sonjo party、Iledaya→Ikedaya に修正しました。

sen.j: 京都守備に当たっていた幕府や会津・薩摩軍と激突し、御所周辺を巻き込んだ合戦が行われた（禁門の変参照）。
sen.e: They had a conflict with armies of the bakufu, Aizu, and Satsuma to develop to a battle extending to the Imperial Palace (see Kinmon Incident).
They clashed with armies of the bakufu, Aizu, and Satsuma, who were defending Kyoto, and a battle extending to the Imperial Palace developed (the Kinmon incident).
They clashed with armies of the bakufu, Aizu, and Satsuma, who were defending Kyoto, and a battle extending to the Imperial Palace developed (the Kinmon incident).

sen.j: この戦で、一敗地にまみれた長州藩は逆賊となり京から追放され、幕府から征伐軍が派遣されることとなる。
sen.e: Because of this battle, Choshu clan was expelled from Kyoto as rebel, against which the bakufu sent the army for conquest.
Because of this battle, the Choshu clan were expelled from Kyoto as rebels, and the bakufu dispatched the army to try and conquer them.
sen.cmt: Wording. The term 'army for conquest' is a bit vague.
sen.e: Because of this battle, the Choshu clan were expelled from Kyoto as rebels, and the bakufu dispatched the army to try and conquer them.
